<span>Reach out to get featured&#8212;contact us to send your exclusive story idea, research, hacks, or ask us a question or leave a comment/feedback!</span>
</a>
</div>

<div class='main-box clear'> <h1 class='story-title-all'>The Hacker News | #1 Trusted Cybersecurity News Site</h1>
<div class='main-left-right clear'>
<div class='left-box' id='left-box'>
<div class='content section' id='content'><div class='widget Blog' data-version='1' id='Blog1'>
<div class='blog-posts clear'>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/new-linux-ransomware-strain-blacksuit.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='New Linux Ransomware Strain BlackSuit Shows Striking Similarities to Royal' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgKj8Z7rui-M7hqSXsiDd70DbOuErF4KYni7y83WYlLpeBp1nurusvmMezzyPLZa0l9-UvbKM9oC8DHlSgZVuOHzJbPvVNw9B0nujVH5QsUsOVUzrzZEkhgKaT__hfAfXfayzK2UbjOxqPCUInGhiYnpFDr5lFkXN69Cbykr8JfVxyBLX3XmehH39Cn/s728-e3650/ransomware.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='New Linux Ransomware Strain BlackSuit Shows Striking Similarities to Royal' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgKj8Z7rui-M7hqSXsiDd70DbOuErF4KYni7y83WYlLpeBp1nurusvmMezzyPLZa0l9-UvbKM9oC8DHlSgZVuOHzJbPvVNw9B0nujVH5QsUsOVUzrzZEkhgKaT__hfAfXfayzK2UbjOxqPCUInGhiYnpFDr5lFkXN69Cbykr8JfVxyBLX3XmehH39Cn/s728-e3650/ransomware.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>New Linux Ransomware Strain BlackSuit Shows Striking Similarities to Royal</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 03, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Endpoint Security / Linux</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> An analysis of the Linux variant of a new ransomware strain called BlackSuit has covered significant similarities with another ransomware family called&#160; Royal . Trend Micro, which examined an x64 VMware ESXi version targeting Linux machines, said it identified an &quot;extremely high degree of similarity&quot; between Royal and BlackSuit. &quot;In fact, they&#39;re nearly identical, with 98% similarities in functions, 99.5% similarities in blocks, and 98.9% similarities in jumps based on BinDiff, a comparison tool for binary files,&quot; Trend Micro researchers&#160; noted . A comparison of the Windows artifacts has identified 93.2% similarity in functions, 99.3% in basic blocks, and 98.4% in jumps based on BinDiff. BlackSuit&#160; first came to light &#160;in early&#160; May 2023 &#160;when Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 drew attention to its ability to target both Windows and Linux hosts. In line with other ransomware groups, it runs a double extortion scheme that steals and encrypts sensitive data in a c</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/cloud-security-tops-concerns-for.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='Cloud Security Tops Concerns for Cybersecurity Leaders: EC-Council&#39;s Certified CISO Hall of Fame Report 2023' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi_ODxROq_IwcKFflnzwC6dPXE1csVUxHC9ULq0tvMKlJDTEMriuSD1-dyN2_5AU5dPTJModHij_81wstl2ORU4nBWpo7Ksc7qlSXLKnENPsQxzWSXkerZbNWSZb54JoKTf9Nckwem5bB3N_ehnZaR5hMZSMIgCZBs8cF1QwnH_yyqLqeao_2Aap4qi/s728-e3650/EC-Council.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='Cloud Security Tops Concerns for Cybersecurity Leaders: EC-Council&#39;s Certified CISO Hall of Fame Report 2023' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi_ODxROq_IwcKFflnzwC6dPXE1csVUxHC9ULq0tvMKlJDTEMriuSD1-dyN2_5AU5dPTJModHij_81wstl2ORU4nBWpo7Ksc7qlSXLKnENPsQxzWSXkerZbNWSZb54JoKTf9Nckwem5bB3N_ehnZaR5hMZSMIgCZBs8cF1QwnH_yyqLqeao_2Aap4qi/s728-e3650/EC-Council.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>Cloud Security Tops Concerns for Cybersecurity Leaders: EC-Council's Certified CISO Hall of Fame Report 2023</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 03, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>CISO / Cybersecurity</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> A survey of global cybersecurity leaders through the 2023 Certified CISO Hall of Fame Report commissioned by the EC-Council identified 4 primary areas of grave concern: cloud security, data security, security governance, and lack of cybersecurity talent. EC-Council, the global leader in cybersecurity education and training, released its Certified Chief Information Security Officer Hall of Fame Report today, honoring the top 50 Certified CISOs globally. This report reveals that approximately 50% of surveyed information security leaders identified cloud security as their top concern. Findings from the report suggest the top cybersecurity concerns with which organizations struggle and highlight the need for implementing robust security frameworks with skilled cybersecurity professionals to effectively contain emerging threats. On average, an enterprise uses approximately 1,295 cloud services, while an employee uses at least 36 cloud-based services daily. Cloud security risk is real for </div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'><a class='story-link' href='https://thn.news/wing-newsfeed-5' rel='nofollow noopener sponsored' target='_blank' title='cyber security'><div class='clear home-post-box cf'><div class='home-img clear'><div class='img-ratio'><img alt='cyber security' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEg6dNJDmPZtqoKxEvJ_tDZVW35mEUpvQRCp-jQxssMXzntvZdTYf5AjZh2fBaGQWbM4EuM2bNC1RCfxAGs-YWusoEdAW2zC-cgJpV0LiXokP4urd2i2LUwDgWtLVni1isYlU4zIikY8vyuY008PapzsRW9EJxangukqVRZwpG49tD2l8YTrzQBNs4vjVQ/s728-e100/DAF.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div></div><div class='clear home-right'><h2 class='home-title'><img alt='external link' class='no-lazy' src='data:image/png;base64,' style=' display: inline-block; max-width: 16px; margin-right: 8px;'/>Say Goodbye to SaaS Blind Spots: Wing Security Unveils Free Discovery Tool</h2><div class='item-label'><img alt='website' class='no-lazy' src='data:image/png;base64,' style=' display: inline-block; max-width: 12px; margin-right: 8px; '/>www.wing.security<span class='h-tags'>SaaS Security / Attack Surface</span></div><div class='home-desc'>Wing Security finds and ranks all SaaS applications completely for free, removing unnecessary risk.</div></div></div></a></div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/ftc-slams-amazon-with-308m-fine-for.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='FTC Slams Amazon with $30.8M Fine for Privacy Violations Involving Alexa and Ring' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEj7F1jzvLv1kMnEj23zNud6N1M3y37hDN-04M5J-JFDs9VzbMTbPlx9vtQQgq_CoWR94H_iUmu1hPSwwJcABazNsWEiLwmjZd3Hf3_Rhi2kaWzhl9YI8kOkpj-oLnIIbKZTFGkVlfSSnxzAAzOX7J47Gu1nUBjbCJf_GJWIwQ9UUY4gIdMpNtf8PIO8/s728-e3650/amazon.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='FTC Slams Amazon with $30.8M Fine for Privacy Violations Involving Alexa and Ring' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEj7F1jzvLv1kMnEj23zNud6N1M3y37hDN-04M5J-JFDs9VzbMTbPlx9vtQQgq_CoWR94H_iUmu1hPSwwJcABazNsWEiLwmjZd3Hf3_Rhi2kaWzhl9YI8kOkpj-oLnIIbKZTFGkVlfSSnxzAAzOX7J47Gu1nUBjbCJf_GJWIwQ9UUY4gIdMpNtf8PIO8/s728-e3650/amazon.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>FTC Slams Amazon with $30.8M Fine for Privacy Violations Involving Alexa and Ring</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 03, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Privacy / Technology</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> The U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has fined Amazon a cumulative $30.8 million over a series of privacy lapses regarding its Alexa assistant and Ring security cameras. This comprises a $25 million penalty for breaching children&#39;s privacy laws by retaining their Alexa voice recordings for indefinite time periods and preventing parents from exercising their deletion rights. &quot;Amazon&#39;s history of misleading parents, keeping children&#39;s recordings indefinitely, and flouting parents&#39; deletion requests violated&#160; COPPA &#160;and sacrificed privacy for profits,&quot; FTC&#39;s Samuel Levine said. As part of the court order, the retail giant has been mandated to delete the collected information, including inactive child accounts, geolocation data, and voice recordings, and prohibited from gathering such data to train its algorithms. It&#39;s also required to disclose to customers its data retention practices. Amazon has also agreed to fork out an additional $5.8 million </div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/new-botnet-malware-horabot-targets.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='New Botnet Malware &#39;Horabot&#39; Targets Spanish-Speaking Users in Latin America' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgetxKzKzSAimMUGLtbZHD9BzAk6ncqnMLkSrTB5lW1-QunbEy9fjQMbWTLh2C9i_i_kyfEwxX9n6Av1GwyMcfyXd8z8zfmwAZJEoY4n5UzkVPX7DOLhW8oiHshhdZhb5CZvM0HEGG12xtNftcSe6MP6pxASDlZ6ZK7Ut0aXmlo6wgA3jiC3DNbqMMS/s728-e3650/phishing.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='New Botnet Malware &#39;Horabot&#39; Targets Spanish-Speaking Users in Latin America' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgetxKzKzSAimMUGLtbZHD9BzAk6ncqnMLkSrTB5lW1-QunbEy9fjQMbWTLh2C9i_i_kyfEwxX9n6Av1GwyMcfyXd8z8zfmwAZJEoY4n5UzkVPX7DOLhW8oiHshhdZhb5CZvM0HEGG12xtNftcSe6MP6pxASDlZ6ZK7Ut0aXmlo6wgA3jiC3DNbqMMS/s728-e3650/phishing.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>New Botnet Malware 'Horabot' Targets Spanish-Speaking Users in Latin America</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 02, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Botnet / Malware</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> Spanish-speaking users in Latin America have been at the receiving end of a new botnet malware dubbed&#160; Horabot &#160;since at least November 2020. &quot;Horabot enables the threat actor to control the victim&#39;s Outlook mailbox, exfiltrate contacts&#39; email addresses, and send phishing emails with malicious HTML attachments to all addresses in the victim&#39;s mailbox,&quot; Cisco Talos researcher Chetan Raghuprasad&#160; said . The botnet program also delivers a Windows-based financial trojan and a spam tool to harvest online banking credentials as well as compromise Gmail, Outlook, and Yahoo! webmail accounts to blast spam emails. The cybersecurity firm said a majority of the infections are located in Mexico, with limited victims identified in Uruguay, Brazil, Venezuela, Argentina, Guatemala, and Panama. The threat actor behind the campaign is believed to be in Brazil. Targeted users of the ongoing campaign primarily span accounting, construction and engineering, wholesale distributio</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/the-importance-of-managing-your-data.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='The Importance of Managing Your Data Security Posture' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi4tJKZFTXNisb1SuCJygdDavtLI8TdWTuE29YWZny1Ysl-2aLv0wSSgyh4Zm1Mpz4yF3-XL3DoakPCdTxUoo_BZn_xhowxa9FyL8YQLEeVAYjW9kP2ahA4XBxFUQ29BI_cOfUN6vsa4fVhRJyOm3XJ1HCSDAkl3Va_42iLfKhqPdsfCG9GzR5dvwSA/s728-e3650/data.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='The Importance of Managing Your Data Security Posture' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi4tJKZFTXNisb1SuCJygdDavtLI8TdWTuE29YWZny1Ysl-2aLv0wSSgyh4Zm1Mpz4yF3-XL3DoakPCdTxUoo_BZn_xhowxa9FyL8YQLEeVAYjW9kP2ahA4XBxFUQ29BI_cOfUN6vsa4fVhRJyOm3XJ1HCSDAkl3Va_42iLfKhqPdsfCG9GzR5dvwSA/s728-e3650/data.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>The Importance of Managing Your Data Security Posture</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 02, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Data Security / Attack Surface</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> Data security is reinventing itself. As new data security posture management solutions come to market, organizations are increasingly recognizing the opportunity to provide evidence-based security that proves how their data is being protected. But what exactly is data security posture, and how do you manage it?&#160; Data security posture management &#160;(DSPM) became mainstream following the publication of Gartner&#174; Cool Vendors&#8482; in Data Security&#8212;Secure and Accelerate Advanced Use Cases. In that&#160; report , Gartner1 seems to have kicked off the popular use of the data security posture management term and massive investment in this space by every VC. Since that report, Gartner has identified at least 16 DSPM vendors, including Symmetry Systems. What is Data Security Posture? There certainly is a lot being marketed and published about data security posture management solutions themselves, but we first wanted to dig into what is data security posture?&#160; Symmetry Systems defines data security pos</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/camaro-dragon-strikes-with-new-tinynote.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='Camaro Dragon Strikes with New TinyNote Backdoor for Intelligence Gathering' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh_w6uFlxq2meswi3Thw7r-i-fg-ueMNDoiOjB_RQoT3y3zN9gYWXpjoMNAzQpWyeHN1B8Cbu7c2mljWQ3MAcUpj6td8vLyCq1Uhm_AXgVElaAjYrf4doFucZh0d7JaR95ZsgBIMQsntc1FgeMm2jY8Ts8FMCqtJUqXZH29hY6NuXi8HePVQtlU5bRV/s728-e3650/dragon.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='Camaro Dragon Strikes with New TinyNote Backdoor for Intelligence Gathering' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh_w6uFlxq2meswi3Thw7r-i-fg-ueMNDoiOjB_RQoT3y3zN9gYWXpjoMNAzQpWyeHN1B8Cbu7c2mljWQ3MAcUpj6td8vLyCq1Uhm_AXgVElaAjYrf4doFucZh0d7JaR95ZsgBIMQsntc1FgeMm2jY8Ts8FMCqtJUqXZH29hY6NuXi8HePVQtlU5bRV/s728-e3650/dragon.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>Camaro Dragon Strikes with New TinyNote Backdoor for Intelligence Gathering</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 02, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Malware / Cyber Threat</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> The Chinese nation-state group known as&#160; Camaro Dragon &#160;has been linked to yet another backdoor that&#39;s designed to meet its intelligence-gathering goals. Israeli cybersecurity firm Check Point, which&#160; dubbed &#160;the Go-based malware TinyNote, said it functions as a first-stage payload capable of &quot;basic machine enumeration and command execution via PowerShell or Goroutines.&quot; What the malware lacks in terms of sophistication, it makes up for it when it comes to establishing redundant methods to retain access to the compromised host by means of multiple persistency tasks and varied methods to communicate with different servers. Camaro Dragon overlaps with a threat actor widely tracked as Mustang Panda, a state-sponsored group from China that is known to be active since at least 2012. The adversarial collective was recently in the spotlight for a custom bespoke firmware implant called&#160; Horse Shell &#160;that co-opts TP-Link routers into a mesh network capable of transmitting co</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/north-koreas-kimsuky-group-mimics-key.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='North Korea&#39;s Kimsuky Group Mimics Key Figures in Targeted Cyber Attacks' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh7HBOo3L1Ch2QxpIE7lfJ2vUrJNRTiHKmffNpZiY1OgxAzSv2hIa3wsyT0EYLufydw0wDTAUy5jcDYxtlmmrBBhTr3X8OHhf8GhgdEuPs1sNFr1W4OP0E9OxUan1k9jL90EaJaqQAbbcpmIe4dJuhTvSizsno0h0fsfP1qaZ1DrW4S4dtfYpITgI4K/s728-e3650/north.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='North Korea&#39;s Kimsuky Group Mimics Key Figures in Targeted Cyber Attacks' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh7HBOo3L1Ch2QxpIE7lfJ2vUrJNRTiHKmffNpZiY1OgxAzSv2hIa3wsyT0EYLufydw0wDTAUy5jcDYxtlmmrBBhTr3X8OHhf8GhgdEuPs1sNFr1W4OP0E9OxUan1k9jL90EaJaqQAbbcpmIe4dJuhTvSizsno0h0fsfP1qaZ1DrW4S4dtfYpITgI4K/s728-e3650/north.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>North Korea's Kimsuky Group Mimics Key Figures in Targeted Cyber Attacks</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 02, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Cyber Espionage / APT</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> U.S. and South Korean intelligence agencies have issued a new alert warning of North Korean cyber actors&#39; use of social engineering tactics to strike think tanks, academia, and news media sectors. The &quot;sustained information gathering efforts&quot; have been attributed to a state-sponsored cluster dubbed&#160; Kimsuky , which is also known by the names APT43, ARCHIPELAGO, Black Banshee, Emerald Sleet (previously Thallium), Nickel Kimball, and Velvet Chollima. &quot;North Korea relies heavily on intelligence gained from these spear-phishing campaigns,&quot; the agencies&#160; said . &quot;Successful compromises of the targeted individuals enable Kimsuky actors to craft more credible and effective spear-phishing emails that can be leveraged against sensitive, high-value targets.&quot; Acting in tandem, South Korea&#39;s Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA)&#160; imposed sanctions &#160;on the North Korean hacking group and identified&#160; two cryptocurrency addresses &#160;used by the entity that have rece</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/moveit-transfer-under-attack-zero-day.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='MOVEit Transfer Under Attack: Zero-Day Vulnerability Actively Being Exploited' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgdOuHnbDe4FXc1azp-jZYn5ZWss8s73iwnbsJx7nB-eCrjs97J8T68LVHFI8aVk5jWquwXXkflmnAiojDu9AklVWg4FDC9FWaFcC5e63lXvF4APLqzj3TXCFmxnLDxffgkBEU1u9yGGzvxKkO3kAdFEGEUPzbscmA-XCwx3RwWxOz62P-3IfSnJ2ir/s728-e3650/moveit.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='MOVEit Transfer Under Attack: Zero-Day Vulnerability Actively Being Exploited' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgdOuHnbDe4FXc1azp-jZYn5ZWss8s73iwnbsJx7nB-eCrjs97J8T68LVHFI8aVk5jWquwXXkflmnAiojDu9AklVWg4FDC9FWaFcC5e63lXvF4APLqzj3TXCFmxnLDxffgkBEU1u9yGGzvxKkO3kAdFEGEUPzbscmA-XCwx3RwWxOz62P-3IfSnJ2ir/s728-e3650/moveit.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>MOVEit Transfer Under Attack: Zero-Day Vulnerability Actively Being Exploited</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 02, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'> Zero-Day / Vulnerability</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> A critical flaw in Progress Software&#39;s in MOVEit Transfer managed file transfer application has come under widespread exploitation in the wild to take over vulnerable systems. The shortcoming, which is assigned the CVE identifier CVE-2023-34362 , relates to a severe SQL injection vulnerability that could lead to escalated privileges and potential unauthorized access to the environment. &quot;An SQL injection vulnerability has been found in the MOVEit Transfer web application that could allow an unauthenticated attacker to gain unauthorized access to MOVEit Transfer&#39;s database,&quot; the company&#160; said . &quot;Depending on the database engine being used (MySQL, Microsoft SQL Server, or Azure SQL), an attacker may be able to infer information about the structure and contents of the database in addition to executing SQL statements that alter or delete database elements.&quot; Patches for the bug have been made available by the Massachusetts-based company, which also owns Teler</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='body-post clear'>
<a class='story-link' href="https://thehackernews.com/2023/06/evasive-qbot-malware-leverages-short.html">
<div class='clear home-post-box cf'>
<div class='home-img clear'>
<div class='img-ratio'><img alt='Evasive QBot Malware Leverages Short-lived Residential IPs for Dynamic Attacks' class='home-img-src lazyload' data-src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjF1-tTxcQcsHt92Ph8x0MihvROKqu3VFsJ-TzEv8zQtjhIkV05DWX6s__AIUJfx3h47gKbwMOYSmejV96fkfiGdpohQ82T99rtv_su4SrBGKEHanTQ8E_nJ2yIKPe5htbQSWy5m9fwKJrVrqtPDfBXjvdMKlCUjBoU7KWAVWmEEL995LJJqaAnUQIY/s728-e3650/black.jpg' decoding='async' height='380' src='data:image/svg+xml;base64,' width='728'/></div>
<noscript><img alt='Evasive QBot Malware Leverages Short-lived Residential IPs for Dynamic Attacks' decoding='async' loading='lazy' src='https://thehackernews.com/new-images/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjF1-tTxcQcsHt92Ph8x0MihvROKqu3VFsJ-TzEv8zQtjhIkV05DWX6s__AIUJfx3h47gKbwMOYSmejV96fkfiGdpohQ82T99rtv_su4SrBGKEHanTQ8E_nJ2yIKPe5htbQSWy5m9fwKJrVrqtPDfBXjvdMKlCUjBoU7KWAVWmEEL995LJJqaAnUQIY/s728-e3650/black.jpg'/></noscript>
</div>
<div class='clear home-right'>
<h2 class='home-title'>Evasive QBot Malware Leverages Short-lived Residential IPs for Dynamic Attacks</h2>
<div class='item-label'>
<span class='h-datetime'><i class='icon-font icon-calendar'>&#59394;</i>Jun 01, 2023</span>
<span class='h-tags'>Cyber Threat / Network Security</span>
</div>
<div class='home-desc'> An analysis of the &quot;evasive and tenacious&quot; malware known as QBot has revealed that 25% of its command-and-control (C2) servers are merely active for a single day. What&#39;s more, 50% of the servers don&#39;t remain active for more than a week, indicating the use of an adaptable and dynamic&#160; C2 infrastructure , Lumen Black Lotus Labs said in a report shared with The Hacker News. &quot;This botnet has adapted techniques to conceal its infrastructure in residential IP space and infected web servers, as opposed to hiding in a network of hosted virtual private servers (VPSs),&quot; security researchers Chris Formosa and Steve Rudd said. QBot , also called QakBot and Pinkslipbot, is a persistent and potent threat that started off as a banking trojan before evolving into a downloader for other payloads, including ransomware. Its origins go back as far as 2007. The malware arrives on victims&#39; devices via spear-phishing emails, which either directly incorporate lure files o</div>
</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
</div>
<div class='blog-pager clear' id='blog-pager'>
<span id='blog-pager-older-link'>
<a class='blog-pager-older-link-mobile' href="https://thehackernews.com/search?updated-max=2023-06-01T21:41:00%2B05:30&max-results=9" id='Blog1_blog-pager-older-link' title='Older Posts'> Next Page <i class='icon-font icon-right-open'>&#59398;</i></a>
</span>
</div>
<div class='clear'></div>
</div></div>
</div>

<div class='pop-desc'>
<div class='pop-title'>New Report Unveils Preferred Hacking Techniques Targeting APIs</div>
</div>
</a>
</div>
<div class='cf pop-article clear'>

//<![CDATA[
function loadScriptAsync(e){const n=document.createElement("script");n.src=e,n.async=!0,document.body.appendChild(n)}function runAfterPageLoad(e){"complete"===document.readyState?e():window.addEventListener("load",e)}
loadScriptAsync('https://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js?client=ca-pub-7983783048239650');
//]]>
</script>
<script async='async' defer='defer' type="da6b6f3d8b4a74685af37818-text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
runAfterPageLoad(function() {
const images=document.querySelectorAll("img[data-src]");let observer;function isInViewport(e){e=e.getBoundingClientRect();return 0<=e.top&&0<=e.left&&e.bottom<=(window.innerHeight||document.documentElement.clientHeight)&&e.right<=(window.innerWidth||document.documentElement.clientWidth)}function lazyLoad(){for(let e=0;e<images.length;e++)isInViewport(images[e])&&loadImage(images[e])}function loadImage(e){e.src=e.dataset.src,e.removeAttribute("data-src"),observer.unobserve(e)}"IntersectionObserver"in window?(observer=new IntersectionObserver(e=>{e.forEach(e=>{e.isIntersecting&&loadImage(e.target)})}),images.forEach(e=>{observer.observe(e)})):(window.addEventListener("load",lazyLoad),window.addEventListener("scroll",lazyLoad),window.addEventListener("resize",lazyLoad));
});
//]]>
</script>
<script async='async' defer='defer' type="da6b6f3d8b4a74685af37818-text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
runAfterPageLoad(function(){for(var e=document.querySelector(".overlay"),o=document.querySelector(".button a"),t=document.querySelector(".share-modal"),l=document.querySelector(".search-box"),n=document.querySelectorAll(".menu-more, .m-menu-more"),c=0;c<n.length;c++)n[c].addEventListener("click",function(){e.style.display="block",o.classList.toggle("btn-open"),o.classList.toggle("btn-close"),document.documentElement.style.overflow="hidden",document.body.style.overflow="hidden"});for(var s=document.querySelectorAll(".btn-close"),c=0;c<s.length;c++)s[c].addEventListener("click",function(){e.style.display="none",o.classList.toggle("btn-open"),o.classList.toggle("btn-close"),document.documentElement.style.overflow="auto",document.body.style.overflow="auto"});for(var r=document.querySelectorAll(".share-show-modal, .fs-more"),c=0;c<r.length;c++)r[c].addEventListener("click",function(){t.style.display="block",document.documentElement.style.overflow="hidden",document.body.style.overflow="hidden"});for(var d=document.querySelectorAll(".share-close-modal"),c=0;c<d.length;c++)d[c].addEventListener("click",function(){t.style.display="none",document.documentElement.style.overflow="auto",document.body.style.overflow="auto"});for(var a=document.querySelectorAll(".search-here, .m-search-here"),c=0;c<a.length;c++)a[c].addEventListener("click",function(){var e=this.querySelector("i"),o=window.getComputedStyle(l).getPropertyValue("display");e.classList.contains("icon-search")?(e.classList.remove("icon-search"),e.classList.add("fa-times")):(e.classList.remove("fa-times"),e.classList.add("icon-search")),l.style.display="none"===o?"block":"none",l.querySelector("input").focus()})});
//]]>
</script>
